F64A63BA44364607987A678031E91BEA.description:
Examine advantages and disadvantages of a growing interdependent world
(e.g., Hundred Years’ War, Crusades, Black Death, cultural diffusion, exploration, education, trade, tributes) D2.His.15.6-8

FC5F5C94EB4446E7A873B2941CC46693.description: Analyze effects of cultural interactions and connections among societies over time (e.g., art, literature, religion, architecture, music, science, technology) D2.His.1.6-8

14790212B8DF446FB76D26501C147DCF.description:
Analyze ways new ideas contributed to the development of the modern world using multiple sources and perspectives (e.g., empire building, Humanism, isolationism, education)
D2.His.2.6-8

F00F62251BAF4A4F8FFE7690FFE23B90.description:
Analyze long-term effects of technological innovations on civilizations
(e.g., Zheng He’s war ships, printing press, Maya calendar, Great Zimbabwe) D2.His.1.6-8

FB950D7B4CC24B61A11B013E7AAC6AE5.description:
Examine effects of invaders from various regions on societies
(e.g., disease, famine, cultural assimilation, Mongols, Vikings, Crusade, Maya, Aztecs) D2.His.15.6-8

3583311B10344597B19447BFDDB5AD34.description: Analyze the global influence and impact of the achievements and perspectives of various individuals (e.g., Gutenberg, Joan of Arc, Niccolo Machiavelli, Saladin, Sundiata Keita, Mansa Musa, Genghis Khan) D2.His.4.6-8

0D14AAA1FCC249C6934659E0DC9C338F.description:
Examine key concepts and influences of major belief systems on societies
 Buddhism
 Christianity
 Confucianism
 Hinduism
 Judaism
 Islam
D2.His.1, 3, 4, 5.6-8

94698C9F88384B45A7354ABEF3A8107E.description: Evaluate how the fall of the Roman Empire affected Europe (e.g., Norse invasions, rise of the power of the Roman Catholic Church, Frankish Kingdoms, Charlemagne) D2.His.15.6-8

8D3A6DBEF36043A290271CD0362FE15F.description: Examine causes and effects of conflict within and among the major empires and civilizations D2.His.14.6-8

027AB46E63DA4BE680BAFC7D514163A1.description:
Analyze the rise and contributions of major empires and civilizations of the world using a variety of sources (e.g., decimal, art, literature, Code of Justinian, Li Bo, Al Bakir)
 African kingdoms
 Byzantine Empire
 Muslim empires
 Tang China
 Maya D2.His.3, 4.6-8

B2EB42CAF5BA42379BC18E098C75DE8E.description:
Examine key concepts and influences of major belief systems on societies
 Buddhism
 Christianity
 Confucianism
 Hinduism
 Judaism
D2.His.1, 3, 4, 5.6-8

EA85009FE19F48559B9B409C27C3620E.description:
Examine causes and effects of conflict within and among the major empires (e.g., Persian War, Punic Wars, Greek city-states)
D2.His.14.6-8

08D0C42CBAD245418C6FB4018E1C5CD2.description: Analyze the significance of contributions made by major empires and civilizations of the world (e.g., concept of zero, crossbow, architecture, government, calendar) D2.His.3.6-8

638409BFF4694350A5D7C50EBECAB684.description: Compare reasons for the rise and decline of major empires and civilizations using a variety of sources  Greece  Gupta  China  Rome  Olmec D2.His.1, 2, 3, 15.6-8

F80558C6570F4F8DAF708229083AA03F.description: Identify social and cultural effects of militarization and the emergence of new kingdoms on early civilizations (e.g., chariot transport, warfare, invaders) D2.His.1, 2, 3, 14, 15.6-8

E8750583C97B4ABE8D072C9B5FE3D4BC.description: Compare characteristics, contributions, and achievements of early river valley civilizations: Mesopotamia	, Egypt, Indus River Valley, China D2.His.1, 2, 3.6-8

0B463FF9A6C04BEB80DBC2EB10255507.description:
Construct arguments about characteristics necessary for a civilization using multiple sources
(e.g., writing systems, government, religion, specialization of labor, technology, economic systems, 
education) D2.His.2, 3, 16.6-8

E87767A313CE47A4A4B2E96761723225.description: Analyze early river valley civilizations to determine similarities and differences, using a variety of sources (e.g., artifacts, Epic of Gilgamesh, hieroglyphics, oracle bones) D2.His.1, 2, 3, 13.6-8; D3.1.6-8

2166A48D1AF7415DAF862814552BADF2.description: Construct arguments about lasting achievements of early civilizations using multiple sources D2.His.3, 10, 16.6-8

8A9BE23E85CF495DA841806E5B94A551.description:
Compare hunter-gatherer and agrarian societies
(e.g., tools, shelter, diet, use of fire, cave paintings, artifacts, clothing, rituals, daily life, gender roles) D2.His.1, 2, 3.6-8
